intro: Willoughbya discolor, commonly known as the African daisy, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters. The plant produces showy, daisy-like flowers in shades of yellow and white, which bloom in late winter to early spring. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in a fine, white powdery coating, known as farina. Willoughbya discolor is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and as a cut flower.
